1.text:
-Fitness and health is about so much more
than exercise and proper eating. It is a catalyst

6.text:
for change and affects every other aspect
of your life. This is the philosophy of my

12.text:
guest today, Tash Weddle, the owner of TNB
Fitness and also a founder of The New Beginning

19.text:
Center where she works with low income women
and transforms their lives through holistic

26.text:
I’m Tajci. At 19 I was a superstar and I
was lost inside. I left it all behind, switched

34.text:
continents and started all over. Years later
I found myself lost again, this time in the

39.text:
American Dream. This is a story about awakening.
About living the life you were created for.

45.text:
About going inward and discovering the joyous
and purposeful person you and I are both meant

51.text: to be. This is Waking Up in America.

54.text: -So much about how we feel about ourselves

58.text:
is connected to our physical self. Often times
it’s easy to get unmotivated to exercise,

66.text:
to move, and yet it’s that physical activity
that our bodies need in order to produce the

72.text:
hormones that make us feel good about ourselves
and also to be healthy. Ever since I started

79.text:
this show I wanted to have a guest that will
talk about this. How to create a turning point

88.text:
at which we say “Yes, tomorrow I’m starting
to take care of myself and my health.” I’m

95.text:
so excited and honored to have Tash Weddle.
Thank you so much.

101.text:
-So you’re… how would you introduce yourself
best?

106.text: -You’re a coach. But not a life coach?

109.text:
-I’m an all kind of coach. What I do, you
can’t just say it’s just nutritional coaching,

115.text:
you can’t just say it’s fitness coaching
because I’m helping people live their best

119.text: life however I can help them do that.

121.text:
-I’m so glad you’re saying that because
oftentimes you know, coach is a fitness coach,

127.text:
or you know, or a life coach and there’s
no connection. So let’s start. I want to

134.text:
know your background. How did you come to
be who you are today?

143.text:
-Well, I started out on a basketball court
in Indiana shooting baskets in Fourth Grade

148.text:
and I did grow to be six feet too tall so
basketball was my destiny.

152.text:
-I got a full scholarship to play in college.
And unfortunately though, before I went to

159.text:
North Carolina State to play I blew my knee
out and tore my ACL. And it’s important

164.text:
to note though that basketball was my identity.
I spent so much time, it was my passion. It

169.text:
was all I ever thought about. And going to
NC State injured meant I have to sit out for

177.text:
a year. I had surgery, I had to sit out for
a year.

179.text: -Oh, wow. Give me the age at that time.

182.text: -Yeah, that’s the time when you are changing.

185.text:
-It’s a major transition, yes. I come back
from that surgery and I do it again. And long

190.text:
story short I had three knee surgeries in
less than two years.

194.text:
-It was. It’s really what I wanted to coach.
It’s all I ever wanted to do. Probably so

199.text:
much my identity that it wasn’t healthy,
you know? And I guess it was a gift, looking

204.text:
back now, those injuries, because it forced
me to go through this transition to rediscover

211.text:
-Yes. And we had many guests on this show
that gets stuck in that identity of their

215.text:
passion and then like you said, you get to
a point in life where you don’t know who you are.

221.text:
-Absolutely. That’s how I felt. And I was
depressed. I couldn’t make myself get out

227.text:
of bed, I couldn’t go to class, and I started
using food—emotional eating. I went from

234.text:
the end of my freshman year I was 140 pounds
to nearly 200 pounds by the end of my sophomore

240.text: year. It was bad and I was miserable.

242.text: -What kind of food were you eating?

243.text:
-Just junk food, just self-medicating, you
know? I go to the gas station, get whatever

251.text:
-Were you aware that you were distracting
and numbing?

254.text:
-Oh, absolutely. But it was an addiction.
And you know, another gift though that I went

259.text:
through that because now with the women I
work with I have walked in their shoes. I

264.text:
see that it’s a very common thing that women
have emotional eating.

267.text:
-Did you feel, I mean, you spent your whole
life, everything you know is exercise regimen,

273.text:
discipline, and so that must have caused a
lot of confusion inside of you.

278.text:
-Yeah, incredible guilt and shame. You know,
I was an athlete and I think I just got so

286.text:
sick and tired I realized that there was nowhere
else to go. The bottom, I had hit the bottom.

291.text:
I didn’t want, you know, to be in this body.
I just wasn’t comfortable. I wasn’t happy.

296.text:
-Was it that one day you walked in the bathroom
and said, “Oh, don’t want to be in that”?

301.text:
-No. I think it was a building up process
that eventually, you know, I believe that

307.text:
people change for two reasons: one, you’re
sick and tired of where you’re at and you’re

312.text:
sick and tired and you’re ready to do something
about it, and the second reason is that you

316.text:
do something that feels good and you feel
successful at and you want that feeling more.

320.text: And that’s exactly what happened for me.

322.text:
-We’re talking to Tash Weddle about the
turning point that happens when we’re sick

327.text:
and tired of being sick and tired. And then
we'll find out when we come back

332.text: what that transformation brought into her life.

353.text:
-Here we are with Tash Weddle, a coach—a
holistic, a whole-person coach

362.text:
-How beautiful. So we’re at the point where
you grew up as an athlete, your dream is shattered

370.text:
when you have the injuries and then you start
eating, emotional eating, which becomes an

375.text:
addiction, and you wake up, which you thought
was overweight.

380.text:
-And then what happened? What are the steps
that you took?

383.text:
-Well, I was dealing with my injuries at that
time. So I walked into the weight room on my

388.text:
own. When you’re on a basketball team you’re
supposed to go workout with the team but I

394.text:
went on my own and I just liked the way it
felt. I was like, “This is where I’m gonna

400.text:
fix this. This is where I’m gonna heal myself.”
And I did.

404.text:
-I imagine, sorry, being a musician I imagine
you walking into a gym late at night, and

409.text:
some beautiful music playing and there’s
Tash picking up a weight. Was it like that?

414.text:
-Well, there usually is music playing in the
weight room.

417.text:
-That’s the only way how I would do it if
it was a movie. But I’m asking because you

422.text: know, that moment is so hard for most of us.

426.text:
-Absolutely. It is so hard to take the first
step. It’s the hardest step to take.

433.text:
-And you found a different kind of satisfaction
in strength training.

437.text:
-It was empowering because I could be successful
still. I mean, even though I wasn’t able

442.text:
to play the sport that I loved, basketball,
I was able to set goals and achieve them.

448.text:
And I’m very goal oriented and I just found
my match. It was also, I was always challenging

458.text:
-Not competing against someone else. And that’s
what I needed at that time. It was just to

465.text:
-Wow. Yes. So once you’re dealing with yourself
is that where your identity is restored? Because

473.text:
it’s still, you’re still immersing yourself
in just a different kind of athletic activity.

478.text:
-Yeah. Well, I did. I loved it so much I transferred
schools, I had a great strength conditioning

484.text:
coach and continued to play basketball and
finish my career. But I was inspired so much

488.text:
by my experience with this coach that I
chose to become a collegiate strength conditioning

493.text:
coach for my career. And I did that for 17
years. And I would say that yeah, I had another

499.text:
you know, that was my identity again. Yeah,
I worked with college athletes, this is an

507.text: important job you know, and it is important.

512.text: -We all get caught in our bubbles.

514.text:
-Yes. Especially when we have success, like
you said.

520.text:
-So then in my 17th year of doing that I realized
there’s a whole world out there and I don’t

527.text:
know anything about it and I’m really tired
of living in this bubble. It was not gratifying

533.text:
work for me anymore. It was all about wins
and losses. It was ups and downs. I lived

538.text:
from season to season just waiting for a break
at that point. I realized I just needed to

543.text:
do something else and so I have taken my skill
set and chosen to start The New Beginning

551.text: Center, which is a nonprofit that helps women.

553.text:
-Yes, and when we were talking, when we were
preparing for this conversation, you mentioned

559.text: you had a friend that was instrumental.

562.text:
-Yeah. So I had all the knowledge I needed
in exercise, nutrition, and coaching and behavior

569.text:
change but I did not have business knowledge
or nonprofit management knowledge. So I had

574.text:
a friend Chris McCarthy who was a Habitat
for Humanity CEO and I was her trainer at

580.text:
that time. And so she suggested this and basically
got the ball rolling.

585.text:
-The reason why I bring this up is because
I always encourage our viewers to be that

591.text:
someone. We all need that someone to give
us that.

594.text:
-The first coach and then a friend to help
us on that transition, point of, and make

602.text:
-That’s absolutely true. I mean, Chris,
a phenomenal woman, but that was such a gift

608.text:
to me but it was meaningful for her too, to
be able to pass on her. She was retiring and

613.text:
she was passing on what she knew to help it
to carry on that.

617.text:
-You know, the beautiful thing I noticed about
guests talking about their turning points

622.text:
is how once we really awaken to the place
of “Who am I? And what is really my purpose?”

631.text:
it seems like there is always that social
enterprise, that giving back, that desire

639.text:
And my guest is Tash Weddle, when we come
back we will talk about The New Beginning

645.text: Center and her work with low income women and transforming their lives.

653.text:
-Do you feel stuck in your life? Are you waiting
for a miracle? Would you like to transform

658.text:
your pain and anxiety to joy and freedom?
Here’s how. The answers are in my book,

663.text:
“Turning Points”. There are dozens of
stories of people like you—people stuck

668.text:
in addictions, abuse, and bad relationships.
But they all took that first step. They all

673.text:
went on a transformational journey and so
can you. Visit WakingUpRevolution.com or Amazon.com

680.text:
or any major online book seller. Get your
copy and turn your life around today.

688.text:
-My guest is Tash Weddle and we’re talking
about an amazing transformation that includes

694.text:
body and mind and spirit, which is actually
what every good life transformation does.

701.text:
-So once you, now you find your identity,
you’re looking for a more purposeful life

709.text:
and you set up New Beginning Center. And you
mentioned, you said something beautiful that

713.text:
athletes are really good as business people
or as workers because you have time management?

726.text:
-Competitive. So tell me about The New Beginning
Center.

730.text:
-It’s been in existence now for nearly five
years. I started our first pilot group with

737.text:
four women just to see how this would go.
And they did phenomenal. They lost 12% of

741.text:
their body weight. It was truly life changing
for these women. I hit the road, foundations

749.text:
are giving money to us. We have fundraising
events, we had this social entrepreneurship

754.text:
with TNB fitness but now we are serving about
380 women a year.

759.text:
-What we do is, it's technically a year-long program
where women, regardless of their ability to

764.text:
pay, can receive free training or sliding
scale fees and they come two to three times

771.text:
a week to our facility and we go through 12
weeks of nutrition coaching and we exercise

778.text:
and we also do some life coaching.
We do personal mission statements, we do vision

783.text:
boards, and things like that. So it’s a
totally new beginning for them.

789.text: -Sounds like a very different way to coach.

793.text:
-It is. Maybe some people consider it a little
New Age-y. But it’s working because we’re

799.text:
achieving about 8% weight loss in 12 weeks,
in the first 12 weeks. And that’s phenomenal.

803.text: That’s enough to reverse Type II Diabetes.

806.text:
-And 67% of the women either decrease or stop
taking their prescription medications.

810.text:
-Wow. That’s amazing. But those women still
have to come to you. They have to have that

820.text:
-They have to have the initial desire to take
the first step. We do have two satellite locations

824.text:
and we hope to expand this model in the future.
I like women to come when they are sick and

832.text:
tired and they’ve tried other things because
then they have a little bit of willingness

838.text:
-Yes, yes. And I think most of us have experienced,
I’ve tried this and it didn’t work and

846.text:
I’m sick and tired of it not working. So
what do you offer that’s different? Like,

851.text: what concrete steps do you offer?

853.text:
-Well, first thing is, we only work on changing
one habit at a time.

859.text:
-Because if we work on one habit you’re
80% likely to be successful with it. As soon

863.text:
as you add a second habit, your success
rate drops to 20%.

866.text:
-Let’s just repeat that. So if you work
on one habit

872.text:
-That you’re changing, you have 80% chance
of success.

878.text:
-So like what would one habit be that I could
start tomorrow?

880.text:
-Our very first habit is to drink 8 cups of
water a day.

884.text:
-And I don’t let people move on until they’re
doing that. And then we want to eat four palms

891.text:
of protein. And we use the hand guide. And
then we want them to eat about four to six

897.text:
fists of veggies. And then we move on to the
carb habit, which we want to eat real food

904.text:
that did not go through a factory. And then
we back up everything too. It’s eating to

912.text:
-So we’re eating mindfully. We’re working
on the mindfulness part.

915.text:
-But each week we roll out a new habit. And
we score their food logs and give them feedback

920.text:
and we talk with them and we find solutions
and we talk about prepping your food at the

925.text:
beginning of the week, setting yourself up
for success. We talk about cleaning out your

929.text:
kitchen with all your trigger foods, setting
yourself up for success.

933.text:
-And just staying focused on that one thing.
And it really needs to be like brushing your

938.text:
teeth. You don’t forget to brush your teeth.
It’s a habit.

942.text:
-That’s really how we want to get these
habits ingrained. They may take years. But

945.text:
they know what they are and they know the
system. Even if they don’t follow them 100%

951.text: of the time they have phenomenal results.

953.text:
-You know what, I’ve heard it so many times,
drink eight cups of water and drink, you know,

960.text:
eat protein and vegetables. We’ve read it
so much and I think everybody knows it. Why

968.text:
-Probably because we have an all-or-nothing
mentality. Guys don’t work 95% of the time,

972.text:
there’s a reason. Because we think it has
to be perfect or we quit. And it’s, you

979.text:
know, we need to have a mind shift of instead
of thinking “I can’t have this,” or

985.text:
“I need to get this out or stop eating that,”
it needs to be, “How many good things that

991.text:
add value to my body can I get in a day? Let
me count the good things I’m doing. Let

995.text:
me focus on what I do need. Let me change
how I do think and identify me. I’m a vibrant,

1001.text: healthy, strong woman who values my health.”

1004.text:
-I eat these good foods. I eat foods that
add value to my body. I don’t diet.

1010.text:
-Yes. So it’s a positive mindset instead
of just like, I was talking to a friend about

1019.text:
having you as a guest today and I said, “I’m
so excited because I never go to the gym,”

1026.text:
so that’s like immediately it’s that negative,
“I never do this,” “I don’t do this,”

1032.text:
-And all these thoughts. We have to shift
in order to adapt these new, good, positive

1037.text:
habits and have success, see the success.
Is that what you’re saying?

1040.text:
-Yeah. I mean, you could change, “I don’t
like going to the gym,” or “I never go

1044.text: to the gym,” to “I enjoy moving my body.”

1048.text:
-And that will take whatever form it should
be.

1050.text:
-And that’s another question, you know.
A lot of people make that turning point, “Okay,

1056.text:
I’m going to be serious about diet and exercise,”
once they have a medical problem.

1060.text:
-And so what we’re exploring in this show
is how can we create these turning points

1065.text:
before the big wake-up call happens? What
is some of the motivation? Like if I came

1071.text:
to you and I said, “Help me to motivate
myself. Help me to be healthy.”

1076.text:
-I think what becomes motivating is it feels
really good to take care of yourself, it feels

1084.text:
really good to prep your food, it feels really
good to get enough sleep at night. It really

1087.text:
feels really good to do all these things.
A lot of people, maybe even normal weight

1093.text: come to me but they don’t feel good.

1095.text:
-They know that something’s missing and
it’s really not about the food, it’s really

1100.text:
not about the exercise. It’s about a lack
of self-nurturing behavior.

1106.text: -And that’s what I want to be addictive.

1107.text:
-But you know, I have viewers who’ll say,
“But Tash, I have kids. I have two jobs.

1116.text:
I can’t. Once I take care of everybody else
I have no energy.”

1123.text:
-I see it all the time—women who have raised
their families and have put themselves last

1128.text:
and they’re tired and they’re exhausted
and they’re kind of resentful about it.

1134.text:
And I mean, I work a lot of hours myself.
I just don’t buy the “I don’t have time,”

1141.text:
because we make time for what we value. And
if you value life and living the fullest life

1149.text: that you can then maybe just take some soul-searching.

1153.text:
-If you value life, take some time to soul
search. Wow. We’re talking to Tash Weddle.

1162.text:
And when we come back we’ll have some more
awesome wisdom.

1168.text:
-Are you planning a live event looking to
bring inspiration and a fresh approach to

1174.text:
wake up your community or organization? Tajci's
keynote concerts are transformational experiences

1180.text:
that lead your audience to a life of joy,
authenticity, courage, and purpose. Book Tajci for

1185.text: your next event now by visiting WakingUpRevolution.com.

1191.text:
-Tash, thank you so much for all the great
tips that you gave us and thank you for listening

1196.text:
to your soul and following your call to helping
others. What I really love is that you have

1205.text:
your TNB Fitness support The New Beginning
Center. So I think that would be one of my

1215.text:
motivations to know that with my membership,
with my working out I’m helping out somebody

1221.text: else. That could get me to a gym.

1223.text:
-It is great motivation for a lot of our clients,
yeah.

1225.text:
-So thank you. And we’ll have links to your
company and if you ever visit Nashville come

1232.text:
stop by. Alright, so I have an email from
a viewer, Stephanie from Cincinnati. And she

1241.text:
says, and I know this is a common problem,
she says, “I get really depressed about

1246.text:
my finances. And when I’m depressed I eat.
And then I become unmotivated to exercise.

1254.text: How can I stop this cycle?”

1255.text:
-I would say that next time have a plan of
just pausing and even if it’s breathing,

1264.text:
five breaths. And it doesn’t even mean that
you have to change your behavior. But you

1270.text:
just have to ask, what am I doing this for?
What do I really want?

1274.text:
-You know what, one thing that I advise my
coaching clients is to practice this when times

1282.text:
are good. To kind of like adopt this practice,
now I want to eat candy well, and I’m not

1290.text:
depressed, I’m going to change that behavior,
have a plan, breathe, and when I’m in a

1295.text:
good place practice that. And so hopefully
you are ready when depression comes.

1304.text:
-And when it comes to exercise it’s been
shown as effective as Zoloft in research.

1310.text:
So it’s funny about exercise, when you feel
depressed you don’t feel like doing it but

1315.text:
doing it would really help your depression.
So sometimes you just have to talk yourself

1321.text:
into getting to the gym or getting in your
gym clothes and by that point you’re good.

1327.text: Five minutes in, you’re not going to stop.

1331.text: -And nobody ever regrets going to the gym.

1334.text: -Alright. Let’s do one word answers. Ready?

1348.text: -All the opportunity and love in my life.

1350.text: -One thing you’d like to be more of?

1368.text:
-If I could abolish anything from the earth
it would be?

1373.text:
-I don’t like sports. I spent my whole life
in them.

1382.text: -Who do you want to help most?

1408.text: -This is such a treat to have Kat Hunter here.

1412.text:
-So when I asked Tash to bring a musical guest
she knew right away who she’s going to ask.

1417.text:
-And I said it would be great if it was your
client. So this is why it’s such a treat

1420.text: because I want to know, is this possible?

1423.text:
-Yeah, it all worked out. It all lined up.
We’re ending the end of the 12-week program

1429.text:
that we were doing so I don’t know if she
kind of threw it out there as a “You gotta

1434.text:
do this.” But no, Tash and I have been friends
for a really long time and I just happen to

1440.text:
have a song that just kind of fit in perfectly
with what she enjoys and kinda where I’ve

1447.text:
been over the last span of 20 years of my
life—pretty much each verse.

1453.text:
-It’s one Decade basically. Yeah, so the
song is Second Wind. It kind of had an athletic

1460.text:
-Oh you mean like the second wind when you
wish you would not have a

1463.text:
-Like when you’re running and you can’t
do any more and all of a sudden that second

1467.text:
wind kinda catches in and you can push a little
further. So it just fit in perfectly.

1472.text:
-So what was your goal, you challenge while
working with Tash?

1477.text:
-First of all, to complete it. Twelve weeks
is a long time and it is a big commitment

1485.text:
but she brings a lot of knowledge, a lot of
encouragement that you can’t get anywhere

1491.text:
else. So when she had the certification and
she said, “Would you be interested in doing

1495.text:
this program?” I was like, “Yes, absolutely.
Sign me up.”

1498.text:
-So Tash, when you have a friend is that harder
than a stranger to work with?

1502.text:
-I actually did a transformation with Kat
many years ago and I knew her work ethic so

1508.text:
I was like, “Yeah, you could do this absolutely,”
because she works hard and I can count on

1512.text:
her to show up. And she’s super easy for
me to coach so I just already knew her character.

1519.text:
-Wow. So do you think other singer-songwriters
can do the same thing?

1524.text:
-Anybody. I mean, the way I coach now is I
meet everyone where they’re at. And it’s

1531.text:
not about meeting my expectation, it’s about
getting a little bit better than you were

1535.text: -Yes. And I can’t wait to hear you sing.

1540.text: -Thank you for having me. Thank you.

1545.text:
-If I had a dime for the dollars I waste
I’d buy myself right out of this place.

1558.text:
Saying why I eat that mid-well steak
Wish I had more time for the dollars I waste

1578.text:
That black warrior rolls right past my home
I’d call my friends but my friends are gone.

1591.text:
Who’s gonna hear my brand new song?
I’d call my friends but my friends are gone.

1603.text:
I think it’s time I hit the road before
I get old

1618.text:
That salt water washing off my feet
That cold still air was sweet but brief

1632.text:
Flown me back where I belong
My heart feels clean now that I’m home

1644.text:
And I’m feeling young again
Think I’ve caught my second wind

1660.text:
Same zip code but a brand new street
Same pillow but a brand new sheet

1672.text:
I feel in love with somebody I know
Right here at home, right under my nose

1685.text:
Now I can hear the song
It’s been playing all along

1718.text:
-What can you do to get out of your cycle
and create that turning point that will shift

1723.text:
you into life in which you’ll feel good
physically, in your mind and in your spirit?

1730.text:
And how would those around you benefit if
you felt healthy and great in your body? And

1739.text:
I do hope that you will share this episode
with your friend, someone you know struggles

1744.text:
with weight or health and could use a little
bit of inspiration. Visit WakingUpRevolution.com

1751.text:
to replay this episode and share it. And there
you’ll find links and more support so that

1757.text:
you can create that turning point in your
life. Thank you so much. We’ll see you again.

1763.text:
-I’m Olga Aleeeva. I’m the artist and
owner of O’Gallery. This episode was filmed

1769.text:
at my studio at Marathon Village, Nashville.
Please visit us at ogalleryart.com. Thank you.
